chapter.title: About This Manual
chapter.para: This document describes the usage of Opics Portal R4.x and its modules for users at the client site. Opics Portal provides online access using web interface to asset services available to your organization through your bank.
It facilitates performing various functions to initiate asset trades, such as Foreign Exchange, Loans, Fund Transfers, etc.

Opics Portal comprises a set of modules performing a similar set of functions, but for different types of trade. Several other modules provide more general facilities, such as the Foreign Exchange module, which helps you to perform an FX trade.

This chapter covers the basic concepts and terminology used throughout the portal. The next chapter Getting Started introduces the Opics Portal and helps you to access it using a web interface. The subsequent chapters provide information about specific modules and their respective functions.
The document also helps you to understand the components of trade calendar used in tracking trade events and describes how to change the profiles of portal users.

section.title: Types of User
section.para: Opics Portal is used by companies that are customers of banks. The terms "customers" and "clients" are used interchangeably in this document.
The portal is generally used by:

listitem.para: A member of the staff of a client who performs trade functions using the portal.
A user with administrative privileges who manages permissions and configurations of the portal.

section.para: The functions available to a user depend on the permissions configured by the administrator.

section.title: Intended Audience
section.para: This document provides information to the end-users at client site and describes the functions available in the client user interface.

section.title: Overview
section.para: This section introduces the basic terminology used throughout Opics Portal.

section.title: Products and Transactions
section.para: In Misys's Portal systems, the different services that a bank can provide are called "products". Therefore, in Opics Portal documentation, we refer to the different asset trade types as products.

The communications between a client and the bank about an individual instance of a product typically consist of a sequence of messages from the client to the bank. For example, the communications regarding a forward FX trade consists of the client's initial request to initiate the trade, possibly followed by a request for an update later.
Note: In Opics Portal, no messages are sent from the bank to the client.

These individual messages are called "transactions" or "transaction events". The entire set of messages concerning one instance of an individual product is called a "file" (represented by a "file of documents" in the system).
The initial request from the client is often called the "initiation" of the file.

section.title: System ID
section.para: When a new file is created – for example, a user initiates a new FX request – Opics Portal assigns it a unique reference number called the System ID. This number is used by the portal to identify it.

section.title: Workflow
section.para: In a typical workflow, as a user representing your organization, you send a request to the bank to initiate a trade. Besides, you can send additional messages to the bank, amending your original request.

Each module provides functions that display the list of transactions that helps you to monitor their progress. When you create a transaction, you can save it without sending it to the bank, so that you or another user can review or amend it later. This status is called Draft or Incomplete.

Nevertheless, while submitting a transaction, if the message is saved but not sent, it indicates that you do not have the designated authority to handle the amount of money involved in the transaction. In such a case, another user, with permissions to perform higher value transactions, can submit it. This status is called Unsigned or Uncontrolled.

section.title: Permissions
section.para: For a user, the access rights to individual modules and functions depend on the permissions configured by your organization’s portal administrator. These permissions in turn are granted to your organization by the bank.
The permissions are often referred to as privileges, authority, or authorization. These four terms are used interchangeably throughout the document.
Caution: The terms permissions, privileges, authority, and authorization do not signify authentication, which means the login credentials to access the portal.
